resources.string: We help with a wide range of tasks you may not know how to do or that don\'t seem to be working properly (such as connecting to devices like printers and phones or figuring out why your computer won\'t start up). We work hard to fix the issue as well as (optionally) explain how to fix it in case it ever reoccurs.

First, let\'s make sure there are available WiFi connections nearby to connect to. This could be either a home network, a coffee shop\'s network, or any other that is available to you. On the bottom-right of your screen, there will be a few icons. Somewhere in there, you will find an icon that looks like a dot with 3 or 4 waves emitting from it (depending on your version of Windows). If you cannot find it, it is likely with the other hidden icons when you click the button that looks like an arrow pointing up. When you click on it, a menu will appear, showing you all of the wireless networks in range.

Now that you have a list of networks, click on one that you wish to connect to and hit "Connect". If it needs a password, it will tell you, but if not, you will soon be connected. If you find yourself not having internet, but are still connected, either the internet\'s down or you haven\'t gone through the internet\'s login page yet. Not all networks have these, but usually public networks do (i.e. Coffee shops, Grocery stores, etc). To access this login page, simply go to any website in your browser and follow the instructions on-screen.
